datafield.subfield: Mass Distribution in Galaxy Cluster Cores

Many processes within galaxy clusters, such as those believed to govern the onset of thermally unstable cooling and active galactic nucleus feedback, are dependent upon local dynamical timescales. However, accurate mapping of the mass distribution within individual clusters is challenging, particularly toward cluster centers where the total mass budget has substantial radially dependent contributions from the stellar (M (*)), gas (M (gas)), and dark matter (M (DM)) components. In this paper we use a small sample of galaxy clusters with deep Chandra observations and good ancillary tracers of their gravitating mass at both large and small radii to develop a method for determining mass profiles that span a wide radial range and extend down into the central galaxy. We also consider potential observational pitfalls in understanding cooling in hot cluster atmospheres, and find tentative evidence for a relationship between the radial extent of cooling X-ray gas and nebular Hα emission in cool-core clusters. At large radii the entropy profiles of our clusters agree with the baseline power law of K ∝ r (1.1) expected from gravity alone. At smaller radii our entropy profiles become shallower but continue with a power law of the form K ∝ r (0.67) down to our resolution limit. Among this small sample of cool-core clusters we therefore find no support for the existence of a central flat “entropy floor.”

Mass distributions can be well modeled by a combination of a singular isothermal sphere component anchored to the stellar mass of the BCG, and an NFW profile fitted to the X-ray data. The effect of the isothermal component continuing to large radii gives 10% uncertainty on the final mass profile out to M2500
Our entropy profiles are best described by a broken power law, which at large radii appears to follow the baseline K ∝ r1.1 scaling expected from gravity alone (Tozzi & Norman,: #apjaa5f56bib121

2005: #apjaa5f56bib129) and at lower radii follows a K ∝ r0.67 scaling as seen in Panagoulia et al (,: #apjaa5f56bib88). We exclude large isentropic cores in these clusters down to our resolution limit (~1 kpc)
We argue that, for clusters containing an obvious central BCG, the BCG represents the best location for the cluster center

Tentative evidence suggests that the cooler component in a two-temperature thermal model fit to central ICM may be associated with extended nebular emission. A single-temperature fit is found to be adequate to trace cooling of the hot phase down to ~1 kpc

The central regions of galaxy clusters (r 20 kpc) are poorly modeled by a constant temperature. Fixing temperature within the inner ~20 kpc leads to errors of approximately 10% on cooling time, which increase at small radii
None of our exploratory sample has tcool/tff below 10, although four out of five exhibit Hα emission indicative of ongoing cooling

We hereafter refer to this cluster as although note that this name is also used in the literature to refer only to the central radio source and/or BCG. This cluster is also often erroneously referred to as A780 in the literature—that cluster is actually a background source with no physical connection Note that is distinct from the (A1060)

Interestingly it was found that the basic SIS model matched the low-altitude mass tracers better than a cored isothermal model with the core radius set to match the stellar core radius. We speculate that this may suggest that at the smallest radii (≤2 kpc) the mass of the supermassive black hole starts to become important to the total mass (see also : #apjaa5f56bib50), but this is beyond the scope of this work
